content:
This Policy will extend to cover accidental loss or damage while in the custody of an airline or other carrier, provided a report is made immediately upon discovery to the airline or other carrier and proof of compensation is obtained or where such compensation is denied, proof of such denial.

We shall have the right to opt to make payment, reinstate or repair any damaged article subject to due allowance for wear and tear and depreciation.

**Pair and Sets Clause**
Where any insured item consists of articles in a pair or set, this Section will not pay more than the value of any particular part or parts which may be lost or damaged without reference to any special value which such article or articles may have as part of such pair or set, nor more than a proportionate part of the value of the pair or set.
questions: How does the policy handle claims for accidental loss or damage to baggage when the items are in the custody of an airline or other carrier, including the timing and type of reports required?
What documentation must be provided to support a claim for loss or damage to baggage while in the custody of a carrier, and how does proof of compensation or denial affect claim eligibility?
In what ways can the insurer settle a claim for damaged articles, and how are wear and tear and depreciation factored into the payment, reinstatement, or repair options?

How does the Pair and Sets Clause limit the amount payable for loss or damage to items that are part of a pair or set, and what implications does this have for the valuation of individual parts versus the whole set?
If an insured item is lost or damaged while in the custody of a carrier but the insured fails to report the incident immediately, how might this affect the claim under this policy section?
When compensation is denied by the airline or carrier for lost or damaged baggage, what proof must the insured provide to maintain eligibility for a claim under this policy?
How does the policy address depreciation and wear and tear when deciding whether to pay, repair, or reinstate a damaged article, and what impact does this have on the claim amount?
In the event of partial loss or damage to a pair or set, how does the policy determine the maximum payable amount, and does it consider any special value of the item as part of the set?
What are the conditions under which the insurer may choose to repair rather than pay for a damaged article, and how does this choice affect the insured's claim?
How does the requirement for an immediate report to the airline or carrier interact with the insured’s obligation to provide proof of compensation or denial to the insurer?

Does the policy provide coverage for loss or damage to baggage that occurs outside the custody of an airline or other carrier, and how does this section’s requirements differ from general baggage coverage?
How might the Pair and Sets Clause affect claims for high-value items that are typically part of a set, such as jewelry or electronic equipment, when only one component is lost or damaged?
What is the insurer’s right regarding reinstatement of a damaged article, and how does this option compare to payment or repair in terms of claim resolution?
If an insured item is damaged but the carrier offers partial compensation, how should the insured proceed to ensure full consideration under this policy section?
How does the policy define the timing for making a report to the airline or carrier, and what are the consequences of delayed reporting on claim validity?
In cases where the insured receives compensation from the carrier, how does this affect the insurer’s liability and the claim settlement process?
What role does the proof of denial of compensation from the carrier play in the claims process, and how must this be documented by the insured?
How does the policy treat claims for items that are part of a pair or set when the lost or damaged part has a higher individual value than the proportionate part of the set?
Are there any exclusions or limitations in this section that override the general policy exclusions related to baggage loss or damage while in carrier custody?

How does the policy ensure fairness in claim settlements involving depreciation, wear and tear, and the special value of items in pairs or sets when deciding between payment, repair, or reinstatement?
